\subsection{Notations and definitions}
We give a few \emph{notations} and \emph{definitions} and then state our main result of this paper.
Let $\Omega\subset\mathbb{R}^3$ be a bounded domain with boundary $\partial\Omega$ of class
$C^{1,1}$. Let $H^\tau(\Omega)(\tau=1,2)$ be the usual Sobolev space on $\Omega$ with
the norm $||\cdot||_{H^\tau}$ and $L^2(\Omega)$ be the Hilbert space with the usual norm
$||\cdot||$. The space $H^1_0(\Omega)$  we mean that the completion of $C^\infty_0(\Omega)$ under the norm $||\cdot||_{H^1}$. If $\digamma$ is a Banach space, we denote by $L^p(0,T;\digamma)$ the Banach space of the $\digamma$-value functions defined
in the interval $(0,T)$ that are $L^p$-integrable.

We also consider the following spaces of divergence-free functions (see Temam [13])
\begin{eqnarray*}

\begin{aligned}
  X&=\{\mathbf{u}\in C^\infty_0(\Omega,\mathbb{R}^3)\  |\  \text{div}\mathbf{u}=0 \ \ \text{in} \  \Omega\},
  \\Y&= \text{the closure of}\  X \  \text{in}\  L^2(\Omega, \mathbb{R}^3)
  \\&=\{\mathbf{u}\in L^2(\Omega,\mathbb{R}^3) \ |\  \text{div}\mathbf{v}=0 \ \ \text{in} \  \Omega\},
  \\W&=\text{the closure of} \ X \  \text{in}\  H^1(\Omega, \mathbb{R}^3)
  \\&=\{\mathbf{u}\in H^1_0(\Omega,\mathbb{R}^3) \ |\  \text{div}\mathbf{u}=0 \ \ \text{in} \  \Omega\},
  \\V&=\{\mathbf{u}\in H^1(\Omega,\mathbb{R}^3) \ |\  \frac{\partial \mathbf{u}}{\partial \mathbf{n}}=0 \ \ \text{on} \  \partial\Omega\}.
\end{aligned}
\end{eqnarray*}
The space $L^2(\Omega, \mathbb{R}^3)$ has the decomposition $L^2(\Omega, \mathbb{R}^3)=W\oplus W^\perp$, where

nexttext:
Therefore, we conclude that there exist $\mathbf{u}\in L^2(0,T; W)\cap L^\infty(0,T; Y)$, $\mathbf{A}\in L^2(0,T; V)\cap L^\infty(0,T; Y)$and $\mathbf{A}_t\in L^\infty(0,T; Y)$ and subsequence,which we still
denote by $\{\mathbf{u}^k \},\{\mathbf{A}^k\}$, $\{\mathbf{A}^k_t\} $ to simplify the notation, such that
text: $$\{\mathbf{A}^k\},\ \{\mathbf{A}^k_t\}  \ \text{are uniformly bounded in } L^\infty(0,T; V)\cap W^{1,\infty}(0,T; Y).$$

^{\infty}(0,T;V)\cap W^{1,\infty}(0,T;Y)." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><msup><mi>𝐀</mi><mi>k</mi></msup><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow><mo rspace="7.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><msubsup><mi>𝐀</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>k</mi></msubsup><mo rspace="7.5pt" stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mtext>are uniformly bounded in </mtext><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>L</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>T</mi><mo>;</mo><mi>V</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>∩</mo><mrow><msup><mi>W</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>T</mi><mo>;</mo><mi>Y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>
